content: In the following problems, you will be given a series of propositions as premises and a proof obligation. The premises are in the form '(1) xxx. (2) xxx. (3) xxx. ...', and the proof obligation is in the form 'Prove: (n) xxx.' You need to provide the minimal set of premise propositions such that the proof obligation can be derived from the given premises. You should present the result in the form '(1),(2),(3),...->(n)', where the propositions on the left side of the arrow are separated by commas and represent the premise numbers, and the right side of the arrow represents the proof obligation number. Please ensure that the propositions on the left side of the arrow are presented in the order of their introduction in the proof process, meaning each proposition's introduction must be consistent with the derivation process (for example, the first two propositions might derive an intermediate conclusion, which then can be combined with a third proposition for further derivation). The answer should only be in the form '(1),(2),(3),...->(n)'.(For each problem, you need to first present three related but not identical problems, along with a description of each problem and its solution. Finally, provide the answer to the original problem in the form of "Therefore, the final answer is: ".)

Premises: [(1) Every numpus is large. (2) Zumpuses are lorpuses. (3) Lorpuses are not wooden. (4) Each gorpus is a jompus. (5) Each numpus is a dumpus. (6) Each dumpus is a sterpus. (7) Each dumpus is bright. (8) Each sterpus is not hot. (9) Jompuses are not sunny. (10) Yumpuses are not opaque. (11) Dumpuses are gorpuses. (12) Every gorpus is brown. (13) Impuses are amenable. (14) Zumpuses are tumpuses. (15) Every impus is a rompus. (16) Each zumpus is sweet. (17) Numpuses are yumpuses. (18) Every gorpus is a zumpus. (19) Fae is an impus. (20) Fae is a numpus.] Prove: (21) Fae is sweet.

Problem 1: 
Premises: [(1) Every x is y. (2) Y is z. (3) Z is w. (4) Each a is b. (5) Each x is c. (6) Each c is d. (7) Each c is e. (8) Each d is not f. (9) A is not g. (10) K is not h. (11) C is bs. (12) Every a is i. (13) M is j. (14) Y is k. (15) Every m is a. (16) Each y is l. (17) X is ms. (18) Every a is x. (19) F is m. (20) F is x.] Prove: (21) F is l.

Problem 2:
Premises: [(1) All p is q. (2) Q is r. (3) R is s. (4) Each t is u. (5) Each p is v. (6) Each v is w. (7) Each v is x. (8) Each w is not y. (9) T is not z. (10) M is not n. (11) V is us. (12) All t is o. (13) S is p. (14) Q is t. (15) All m is t. (16) Each q is r. (17) P is ts. (18) Every t is p. (19) F is m. (20) F is t.] Prove: (21) F is s.

Problem 3:
Premises: [(1) Every animal is alive. (2) Lions are predators. (3) Predators are carnivores. (4) Each tiger is wild. (5) Each animal is big. (6) Each big animal is dangerous. (7) Each big animal is fierce. (8) Each dangerous animal is not friendly. (9) Tigers are not domesticated. (10) Elephants are not tiny. (11) Antelopes are prey. (12) Every tiger is striped. (13) Each lion is yellow. (14) Wolves are not herbivores. (15) Every bear is a threat. (16) Each lion is an animal. (17) All tigers are lions. (18) Every tiger is a big cat. (19) Fido is a lion. (20) Fido is a tiger.] Prove: (21) Fido is striped.

Therefore, the final answer is: (19),(20)->(21)

Premises: [(0) Every mother has a son. (1) Every numpus is large. (2) Zumpuses are lorpuses. (3) Lorpuses are not wooden. (4) Each gorpus is a jompus. (5) Each numpus is a dumpus. (6) Each dumpus is a sterpus. (7) Each dumpus is bright. (8) Each sterpus is not hot. (9) Jompuses are not sunny. (10) Yumpuses are not opaque. (11) Dumpuses are gorpuses. (12) Every gorpus is brown. (13) Impuses are amenable. (14) Zumpuses are tumpuses. (15) Every impus is a rompus. (16) Each zumpus is sweet. (17) Numpuses are yumpuses. (18) Every gorpus is a zumpus. (19) Fae is an impus. (20) Fae is a numpus.] Prove: (21) Fae is sweet.

Problem 1: 
Premises: [(0) Every m is s. (1) Every x is y. (2) Y is z. (3) Z is w. (4) Each a is b. (5) Each x is c. (6) Each c is d. (7) Each c is e. (8) Each d is not f. (9) A is not g. (10) K is not h. (11) C is bs. (12) Every a is i. (13) M is j. (14) Y is k. (15) Every m is a. (16) Each y is l. (17) X is ms. (18) Every a is x. (19) F is m. (20) F is x.] Prove: (21) F is l.

Problem 2:
Premises: [(0) Every r is q. (1) All p is q. (2) Q is r. (3) R is s. (4) Each t is u. (5) Each p is v. (6) Each v is w. (7) Each v is x. (8) Each w is not y. (9) T is not z. (10) M is not n. (11) V is us. (12) All t is o. (13) S is p. (14) Q is t. (15) All m is t. (16) Each q is r. (17) P is ts. (18) Every t is p. (19) F is m. (20) F is t.] Prove: (21) F is s.

Problem 3:
Premises: [(0) Each parent has a child. (1) Every animal is alive. (2) Lions are predators. (3) Predators are carnivores. (4) Each tiger is wild. (5) Each animal is big. (6) Each big animal is dangerous. (7) Each big animal is fierce. (8) Each dangerous animal is not friendly. (9) Tigers are not domesticated. (10) Elephants are not tiny. (11) Antelopes are prey. (12) Every tiger is striped. (13) Each lion is yellow. (14) Wolves are not herbivores. (15) Every bear is a threat. (16) Each lion is an animal. (17) All tigers are lions. (18) Every tiger is a big cat. (19) Fido is a lion. (20) Fido is a tiger.] Prove: (21) Fido is striped.

Therefore, the final answer is: (19),(20)->(21)
